cleaned_text: help The malfunction of the thyroid is one of the fastest growing disorders in modern times. Thyroid is a gland in the front of the neck that controls metabolism, or how the body turns food into energy and also affects the heart, muscles, bones and cholesterol. Excessive secretion of thyroid hormones in the body is called hyperthyroidism. In this medical condition, the thyroid gland is overactive. Causes of hyperthyroidism Some common causes of hyperthyroidism are: - Graves' disease: It is the main cause of hyperthyroidism. It is an autoimmune disorder in which the antibodies are produced by the immune system against its own tissue and attack the thyroid gland, resulting in excessive production of thyroid hormones. This leads to hyperthyroidism. - Thyroiditis: The inflammation of the thyroid gland leads to increased production of thyroid hormones leading to hyperthyroidism. - Excessive intake of thyroid hormone supplements: This is a rare cause of hyperthyroidism. If a patient of hypothyroidism who is not under regular follow up and continue to take the same dosage of the supplement might be taking excessive amounts of thyroid hormone than required which causes hyperthyroidism. - Excessive iodine intake: Although a rare case, ingestion of excessive iodine can lead to excessive production of thyroid hormones leading to hyperthyroidism. Symptoms of hyperthyroidism Increased secretion of thyroid hormones can produce uncountable symptoms that vary from person to person and with the age of the patient. The common [symptoms of hyperthyroidism](https://www.drbatras.com/hyperthyroidism/symptoms) include: - Unexplained changes in weight - Increased appetite - Rapid or irregular heartbeat - Heat intolerance - Nervousness - Insomnia - Difficulty in breathing - Increased bowel movements - Irregular periods - Weakness - Tremors of hands and fingers - Irritability - Excessive perspiration - Feeling moody - Feeling agitated - Excessive sweating - Decreased concentration All the symptoms listed above may or may not be present in every person with hyperthyroidism.
